description.narrative: INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK TOURISM PROJECT; Private sector Support Project; Aid Coordination Project

title.narrative: Private and Financial Sector Devt_ 2016 AWP

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Number of country diagnostics carried out to inform policy options on national response to globally agreed development agenda, including with analysis of sustainability and risk resilience
Number of new public-private partnership (PPP) mechanisms that provide innovative solutions for development
number of pilots and demonstration projects initiated by national partners
number of pilots and demonstration projects scaled up by national partners
Support to PPP and BoSL
independent political entity
Number of technical support, methodology document prepared and PPP investment deals supported Number of BoSL Research staff trained and number and type of support provided

comment.narrative: Initial legal and institutional framework in place; capacity for soliciting small scale service delivery and local content centered PPP investments is weak and scattered; Limited financial services to more than half of the population

1. a) at least 2 PPP Agreements signed/reviewed b) Medium - Improved technical capaicty to carry out work of PPP unit
2. Training on inclusive financial policy analysis and benchmarking

The Unit has completed implementation on all activities viz PPP-specific training for staff, procurement of IT network configuration service, upgrade of the PPP Web Site content to improve sensitization on procurement process and best practices, support to PPP Unit capacity with office equipment and stationary and regional training workshop on PPP/PPCP fundamentals and benefits

description.narrative: Support to Access to Justice in Sierra Leone through increased application of human rights standards, effective implementation of relevant national legislation and adoption of gender-sensitive practices in both formal and customary justice systems.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of men with access to legal aid services
Number of women with access to legal aid services
Total number of people with access to legal aid services
Number of GBV cases receiving judgment in the first instance of the formal justice system
Number of non-GBV cases receiving judgment in the first instance of the formal justice system
Support to Access to Justice in Sierra Leone
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

An existing Strategic Plan and legislative manual % decrease in the number of SGBV cases at national and local levels % change in number of SGBV cases cleared by Saturday courts and mobile courts and % of magistrate servicing the provinces Number of legal support at local level disaggregated by gender and age; Number of public awareness campaigns by the media and CSO at district and local level

comment.narrative: In 2010 55,610 criminal cases were reported to police only 666 were prosecuted in court 547 SGBV cases backlogged in 2011

The implementation of the newly developed Legislative Drafting Manual and Guidance Notes for MDAs is effective; SGBV courts/itinerant courts functioning effectively in Freetown, Port Loko and Kono; Support provided to 700 victims of SGBV; 6,000 cases monitored across Local Courts and Magistrates Courts with 1,500 perception survey questionnaires administered; support to 250,000 rural community residents with EVD prevention kits and response messages.

In order to operationalize the Legislative Drafting Manual and Guidance Notes process for Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs), the Law Officers’ Department of the Ministry of Justice convened at total of 48 MDAs (Permanent Secretaries of Ministries, and other senior civil servants) at the Civil Service College in Freetown in March 2015. The essence of the meeting was to acquaint MDAs with the process involved in initiating legislation in their respective units through the steps as highlighted in the developed Manual.
In an effort to reactivate justice services amidst negative impacts of the EVD outbreak, the Judiciary through UNDP support organized extra sittings of the High Court and Magistrates’ Courts in Freetown and the High Courts in Port Loko and Moyamba. In Port Loko, 42 cases were waiting to be heard by the High Court and two thirds of these were all cases committed in 2014 – indicating that the Court had not been on circuit to the district for the majority of 2014 and not before UNDP’s support in 2015. 17 of these cases were completed during the special session with 8 partly heard and adjourned to next session in June 2015. The remaining cases lacked indictments and witnesses had not been summoned. In Moyamba, out of 36 cases assigned for trial, 24 cases were completed. The remaining cases could not be completed due to lack of witnesses/evidence and absence of the accused persons. Magistrates’ courts in Freetown heard 40 cases with 17 judgments delivered, 7 committals, 9 discharges and 4 thrown out of court for lack of evidence and 3 adjourned. The High Court circuit in Kono enabled the hearing of 54 cases and the 300 cases were submitted to the Magistrate’s Court for hearing and determination.
6 CSOs were supported to provide assistance to victims of SGBV in 2015, especially given reports of increased SGBV cases as a result of the crisis. On average, CSOs provided support to 60 victims of SGBV to access medical care and legal remedies; to f

At least 1,000 people benefit from mobile court sessions; Needs assessment is complete and a comprehensive report on a case management needs for the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is produced. 80 convictions by 2016 on SGBV matters charged to court.

A total of at least 1,100 people have benefited from the special backlog court sittings in 3 High Courts in Freetown, 1 High Court in Bo and 1 High Court in Moyamba. In Moyamba, the Circuit HC heard 73 cases with 33 completed and 40 adjourned to the next session. 41 cases were heard in 2 Magistrates’ Courts in Freetown while 12 cases were adjudicated by 1 High Court in Freetown A needs assessment on a case management system needs was conducted by an independent consultant to determine the actual needs of the Ministry of Justice. The scoping exercise was aimed at identifying the existing needs of the entire the ministry of justice in terms of case management system and to determine a suitable solution for this purpose. The consultant interfaced with all heads of departments, the Minister and Deputy as well as the DPP, the Solicitor General and the Permanent Secretary. Concrete recommendations have been made in the final report for future consideration in the development of a case management system for the Ministry. With the limited funds available, 2 national NGOs were supported to provide assistance to victims of SGBV to access medical centers, police stations for investigation and to attend court sittings to improve the chances of securing a conviction for offences suffered. Within 2016, 95 cases were investigated, charged to court or dismissed for several reasons. On the outcome of court cases, 30 convictions were secured with over 56 matters still ongoing. Challenges associated with securing a conviction pertain to the distances to access court session, the compromise of cases at community levels and the unwillingness of victims and their families to abandon activities relevant to their survival to attend court sessions.

description.narrative: Capacity Development of the Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

• State Human Right Report produced • # of Detention centre inspected • Quarterly news letter produced • # of Books and journal procured for resource centre • TRC records digitised • Consultant hired for digitization of TRC records • # of community awareness programmes on rights, duties and responsibilities produced and aired • # of staff trained

comment.narrative: •No formal Procedures for receiving, registering and verifying complaints by the Human Rights Commission of Sierra •Limited Capacity of civil society organizations to promote and monitor justice delivery to the poor •Limited Capacity of MPs increased to promote human rights through their legislative and oversight roles

-300 cases received and handled(F140,M 160) -20 group discussions nationwide with stakeholders to inform the SOHR report -2 Civil society trainings and 3 government engagements on UPR -5 investigations carried out, matrix to track treaty body reporting requirements produced and followed -3 curricula for human rights education produced -10 outreach sessions and media engagements on salient human rights issues

-300 cases were received and handled (F140,M 160) accross the country -20 group discussions were conducted nationwide with stakeholders to inform the 2015 SOHR report -conducted 2 Civil society trainings and 3 government engagements on UPR -5 investigations carried out and a matrix developed to track treaty body reporting requirements produced and followed -Developed 3 curricula for human rights education and distributed across the country -Held 10 outreach sessions and media engagements on salient human rights issues across the country

UNDP supported the HRCSL in the development of the State of the Human Rights Report 2015 that has been finalized and submitted to his Excellency the President Ernest Bai Koroma. The Commission with support of technical expertise from the OHCHR trained Commissioners and key staff on treaty body reporting to ensure for improvement in monitoring, collecting data and finalizing reports to the treaty bodies. Furthermore, the HRCSL was supported to develop the design and hosting of their new website, and finally, was supported in celebrating 10 December 2016 International Human Rights Day.

- 40 admissible complaints received in 2017 - 15 investigations completed in 2017 - 1 public hearing held (where necessary - 3 engagements with stakeholders on rights of vulnerable groups - 2 engagements with referral partners to monitor the progress of cases referred to them by HRCSL - The SoHR Report 2016 developed - 10 inspections visits conducted by the 5 human rights offices in 2016 - A functional human rights working group

description.narrative: Credible elections for Parliamentary seats and support to the Parliament has provided an opportunity for MPs effectively realize their mandates towards the peaceful resolution of ethnic differences and lessening of traditional tribal animosities.

Parliament project aims to strengthen capacity of parliament to effectively carry out its legislative, representative oversight functions as well as perform its central role of ensuring reconciliation and securing lasting peace for the country.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

Number of parliamentary assistance and assistance coordination offices operational , number of constituency outreach undertaken by MPs Number of MP capacity building completed and number of parliamentary assistance coordination offices operational

comment.narrative: A new Parliament in place with 70% first timers; standing Order (SO) does not reflect the changes in the management of the Parliament 70% of MPs have no parliamentary experience

1. Concept developed and parliament budget office begins functioning 2. 15 staff of parliament benefit from specialised training on bill drafting 3. Audio visual unit established and records 10 radio programs 4. 3 schools/education institutions reached by staff of parliament/MPs 5. PACO is very good in coordinating the work of parliament 6. At least 5 gender issues taken up by the Committee on Social Welfare

Peer learning visit by key Parliament staff and a few MP's to the Parliament of Ghana and Parliament of Uganda completed. Concept on the Parliament Budget Office developed and shared. Specialized training on Legislative process within Parliament held for key staff; Workshop on essentials of Bill drafting held. increased clarity on challenges encountered in the legislative business of the House. Legislative Department reaches out to schools; Presentations prepared on key topics and event held with participation of few MP's. Students got briefed for the first time on actual parliamentary working. PACO effectively managed the donor support in Parliament- UNDP, UNICEF, ACBF, CPA and other stakeholders. New partner has come on board for Parliament, namely, Westminster Foundation for Democracy (WFD).

description.narrative: Preventive Development Support on Disaster Risk Management

title.narrative: AWP for SDGF project in Kono

description.narrative: The project aimed at strengthening the policy framework and institutional arrangements for managing natural resources and addressing land tenure, climate change, disaster, and environmental management.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

? National Training Action plan developed and validated ? Institutions, Mechanisms and Capacities strengthened for rapid responses to national disasters at all levels ? Review and integrate Guidelines on International Disaster Relief into national DRM policy and action plan ? Conduct Risks and vulnerability profiles for selected districts

comment.narrative: Disaster preparedness, risk reduction and response strategies are integrated into national development planning

- Cabinet approved Land Policy - Development of a Position Paper on NRM and environmental sustainability for the Constitutional Review process - Domestication of the Natural Resource Charter Benchmarking Precepts - Development of the National Position Paper and participation in UNFCCC COP21/CMP11 - Establishment of South-South collaborative framework with Liberia for Biodiversity conservation in the common Protected Area at Gola - Development of SOP for District Disaster Management Committees

- Land Policy was approved by Cabinet in November 2015 - A Position Paper on NRM and environmental sustainability was submitted to the Constitutional Review Committee resulting in a new chapter in the Constitution on natural resource management as a national priority - The Natural Resource Charter Benchmarking Precepts was domesticated and is to form part of the National Mining Policy that is being developed - The National Position Paper was developed and SL participated in UNFCCC COP21/CMP11 - The NPAA and its Liberia counterpart signed a MOU on South-South collaboration for Biodiversity conservation in the common Protected Area at Gola - The SOP for District Disaster Management Committees was developed though not validated

1. Development and endorsement of the Core Minerals Policy based on the African Mining version 2. Development of a 5-Year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy 3. Finalisation and publication of the State of Environment Report 4. Capacity building for centralised GIS database management and information dissemination 5. Facilitation of a dialogue platform for natural resource governance 6. Training of NPAA staff on forest landscape restoration 7. Acquire high resolution satellite images for nation-wide assessment of forest cover. 8. Nationwide popularisation on relevant provisions of the Disaster Risk Management Policy 9. Facilitate the strengthening of effective DRM response mechanisms

1. Development and endorsement of the Core Minerals Policy based on the African Mining version 2. Development of a 5-Year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy - A 5-year Roll Out Plan for Core Minerals Policy has been developed and validated which will serve as the road map for the implementation of strategies outline in the core minerals policy 3. Finalisation and publication of the State of Environment Report - The inaugural State of Environment Report has been published and launched by the EPA with support from the UNDP. The UNDP supported Coastal Sensitivity Maps was also officially launched. 4. Capacity building for centralised GIS database management and information dissemination - Equipment has been procured and installed to enhance the overall capacity of the EPA with the GIS database management and information dissemination. Support was also provided to the EPA Kono Office on GIS mapping for environmental governance
5. Facilitation of a dialogue platform for natural resource governance - One meeting was held with key environmental CSOs and NGOS and the Academic to facilitate the establishment of a platform for catalytic civil society engagements on natural resources management issues in Sierra Leone 6. Training of NPAA staff on forest landscape restoration - A staff of the NPAA has been trained by the US Forestry Department/Office of International Programs on forest landscape restoration. The NPAA staff is now a trainer for other foresters and park management officers and this training has been put into use with the establishment of new protected areas in the country. 7. Acquire high resolution satellite images for nation-wide assessment of forest cover. - High resolution satellite images have been procured from NASA for the NPAA for nation-wide assessment of forest cover which covers a forest cover of the country at 35%.
8. Nationwide popularisation on relevant provisions of the Disaster Risk Management Policy - Various awareness raising activities

• Popularization and launch of the National Land Policy Roll, Sierra Leone Minerals Policy and NRC benchmarking report, National Disaster Risk Management Policy • Capacity enhancement and technical support to Ministry of Mines and Mineral Resources and the newly established Policy Directorate in order to implement the 5-year Strategic Plan • Alignment of the NDC implementation with ongoing initiatives • Reform/Revision of the present current Climate Change Policy and drafting of the Climate Change Bill and Associated Strategic Plan • Conduct of the Village to Village Environment Education and Biodiversity and Conservation Education Strategy • Development of a legal, policy and regulatory support for revenue sharing within the PA communities • Review / Reform the National Hazard Profile • Training on technical skills on data collection, interpretation and analyzing of DRM data

Youth Employment and Empowerment
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

# of young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful intenship opportunities, career advice and entrepreneurship development services (disaggregated by gender) # of youth engaged in agribusiness projects a) # of coordination actions (Minutes of coordination/collaboration meetings with MDAs and key partners) b) # of capacity support provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

comment.narrative:
6 BDS centres established, 5 CAPS centers established, GIP placed 770 interns
6 Technical Staff supported at MoYA, 12 Coordination meetings held with stakeholders, The National Youth Policy reviewed and launched, the National Youth Service scheme passed into an Act by Parliament.

3000 young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful work experience and employment opportunities (disaggregated by gender)
XXX Coordination decisions and minutes/reports xxx capacity support provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

Growth and development are inclusive and sustainable, incorporating productive capacities that create employment and livelihood for the poor and excluded. - 5 BDS Centres fully operatioinal  135 (79 Male; 26 Female) youth enterprises were expanded.  186 (109 Female; 77 male) Businesses were mentored for growth and for expansion.  74 (59 Male; Female 15) Businesses were registered through NASSIT and Local Councils at community level.  197 Businesses (105 Male; 92 Female) received access to finance, either through grants from the Business Plan Competition (BPC) or through support to Ebola affected businesses, during the Ebola outbreak.
70 graduates (32 Male; 38 Female) trained, were able to start new business through the Business Plan Competition. (See Table 1 and figure 1 below). - 5 Career Advisory and Placement Services (CAPS) Centres are providing services to an average of 100 graduates per month enhancing their employability for the labour market. Provision of advice, computer training, support services and internship will also enable young people to choose careers which are more in line with their interest and competencies. - 100 pupils in 5 Secondary School have received outreach career advisory services which will empower them to make realistic decisions and informed subject choices which will further help them as they transition from secondary school to higher learning and eventually for the labour market. - 203 (Male 142; Female 61) Interns at placed at various institutions, have gained meaningful work ethics experiences for sustainable employment.. - 180 youths have acquired enhanced capacities for value chain addition for priority products, formation of agribusiness cooperatives and access to finance. - Skills trains in various skills provided to 125 youths in Kono District, has provided employment for over 50% of these youths. - Capacity development training of 28 District Youth Council (DYC) Executive Members will enhance their skills in proj

1500 young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful internship opportunities, career advice and employment opportunities (disaggregated by gender); 240 youth engaged in agribusiness projects 1 5 Coordination decisions and minutes/reports b) capacity support activities provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

. - 3 BDS centres effectively operational in three districts have provided business entrepreneurial trainings, including the provision of grants through the Business Plan Competition (BPC) to 150 youths, (Female 66: Male 84), thereby enhancing business skills of beneficiaries. This training havel enbled them to have improved access to sustainable income generating opportunities Additionally, a total of:
- 68 youth (9 Female 39, Male 29) have expanded their Small and Medium Enterprises (SME) as a result of the BDS intervention. - 38 youth businesses have been registered through the local town and city councils and some with National Social Security and Insurance Trust (NASSIT) - 260 existing Business Operators have received mentorship, coaching service, thus increasing their potential for business growth and diversification. - 384 Ebola burial team volunteers who received entrepreneurial training at the 3 BDS Centres have helped to reintegrate and empower the burial team workers, through the establishment of SMEs and/or other self employment opportunities. - 150 youths (68 females and 132 males) at the Obasanjo Skills and Acquisition Centre, whose skills have been enhanced through enterprise management training, have been capacitated for business expansion, self-employment and other career opportunities. - 4 Career Advisory and Placement Services (CAPS) Centres are providing services to an average of 100 graduates per month enhancing their employability for the labour market. Provision of advice, computer training, support services and internship will also enable young people to choose careers which are more in line with their interest and competencies. - 100 pupils in 5 Secondary School have received outreach career advisory services which will empower them to make realistic decisions and informed subject choices which will further help them as they transition from secondary school to higher learning and eventually for the labour market. - 280 interns p

Output 1 - 4,935 young people (age 15-35) gaining meaningful internship opportunities, career advice, innovations in IT and employment opportunities (disaggregated by gender
Output 2 - 15 Coordination decisions and minutes/reports b) capacity support activities provided to MoYA, NAYCOM and DYC

Entrepreneurial competencies of 150 youth developed through the operation of 5 established Business Development Centers
Five (5) CAPS centers are operational and able to reach up to 100 youth per Centre per month.
130 Graduates for Tertiary Institutions trained and placed in various institutions.
Youth Innovation in IT and entrepreneurship promoted
Youth policies/strategies are mainstreamed within the MDAs and development partners.
Implementation of youth development activities is effective and well coordinated by MOYA/NAYCOM

description.narrative: Supporting media capacity building and development in Sierra Leone
Capacity of democratic institutions including Electoral Management Bodies, Parliament and Media enhanced to promote democratic governance
independent political entity
Elections - elections

- National Media Development Strategy Document - Media Reform Coordination mechanism (MRCG -SL) - Codified/draft Media Bill - Self-regulatory instruments for media (Press Freedom Charter and SLAJ Code of Practice) - Revised media education curriculum and trained staff at the Mass Communication Department, Fourah Bay College - Strengthened national media organizations (building blocks for media reform)

comment.narrative: - No National Media Development Strategy - No Codified media law and non-existent effective self-regulatory framework for media - Inadequate media coordination mechanism - Weak media organizations - Mass Communication Department, Fourah Bay College lack appropriate media education curriculum and adequately trained staff -

- SLAJ code of ethics revised and enforced - Media bill enacted into Media Law - Cooperation agreement on Broadcast licences developed and signed between NATCOM and IMC - Nineteen community radio in the provinces are logged on the Stirlitz (Electronic Radio Monitoring System) - Mass Communication syllabi developed for core courses - Course Handbook developed. - Mass Communication syllabi developed for core courses - Course Handbook developed - Two national collaborative media activities executed

- SLAJ Code of Ethics revised and popularised - Media Bill presented to Ministry of Information and Communication, Attorney General's office and the Law Reform Department for final review and submission to the Sierra Leone Parliament. - Cooperation Plan between IMC and NATCOM is to be formulated - Nineteen community radio stations logged on the Stilitz Electronic Radio Monitoring System - Mass Communication syllabi developed for core courses - Mass Communication syllabi developed. Course Handbook developed - State of the Media Report 2015 developed

- Civil Libel Law reviewed and popularized. - Media directory developed and publicized. - Four complaints committee meetings held. - IMC (Independent Media Commission) Strategic plan reviewed/rolled out. - Signed MOU between IMC and NATCOM on allocation of National Spectrum. - Media training database established and operationalized - MOU Signed among Media Schools for the roll out of media syllabi - Composite business (printing press) plan developed - Community Radio Station Governance and newspaper distribution guidelines developed - Establish systems and procedures on Financial management, procurement, project monitoring and evaluation - Four staff sessions conducted for MRCG Secretariat staff - Two national collaborative media activities executed

title.narrative: Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change

description.narrative: The project seeks to enhance the adaptive capacity of decision-makers in the public and private sector involved in water provision to plan for and respond to climate change risks on water resources

title.narrative: Adaptive Capacity of water Services to Climate Change_(GEF)_AWP 2016
Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change
Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change
Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change
Adaptive Capacity of Water Services to Climate Change

description.narrative: The project seeks to enhance the adaptive capacity of decision-makers in the public and private sector involved in water provision to plan for and respond to climate change risks on water resources

- # of climate change resilience plan for Guma reservoir established - # of people accessing safe water supply services at projected climate change affected communities - % change of key decision-makers with limited knowledge of climate change impacts or adaptation responses - Number of strategic documents produced and used in tackling climate change issues in the country

comment.narrative: - No climate change adaptation concerns and actions mainstreamed within the Guma Reservoir Management process - Zero additional people provided with access to safe water supply services at projected climate change affected target communities - Baseline capacity assessment to be undertaken at project onset
Development of a climate change resilience plan for Guma reservoir
Consultancy notice for the development of a climate change resilience plan for Guma reservoir initiated

1. Updated Water Point and Groundwater mapping tools to adapt them to new aspects of climate changes developments within pilot communities 2. Commission a climate change resilience plan and emergency contingency plan for the Guma Reservoir 3. Construct the rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs at Ministry of Water Resources Tower Hill Office, Ola During Children’s Hospital and the Renewable Training Centre at Sussex 4. Build and implement innovation demonstrations on spring boxes improvement in 5 demonstration sites in Kambia and Freetown 5. Drill boreholes and distribution mechanisms in twelve communities in Pujehun, Kono, Kambia and Freetown 6. Provide water storage and treatment systems to at least 20 households in Kono and Kambia

1. Updated Water Point and Groundwater mapping tools to adapt them to new aspects of climate changes developments within pilot communities - With support from the Ministry of the Water Resources, exercise was conducted to map out the nationwide water points and guide tool developed to ensure existing and any new water points are adapted to new aspects of climate changes
2. Commission a climate change resilience plan and emergency contingency plan for the Guma Reservoir - A Climate Change Resilience Plan and Emergency Contingency Plan has been developed for the Guma Reservoir. Trainings were also conducted for staff of the Guma Valley Water Company on the operationalisation of the Plan.
3. Construct the rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs in MRW, Murray Town Hospital and EFA buildings - Design for the construction of rooftop rainwater collection with reservoirs in the Ministry of Water Resources Tower Hill Office, Ola During Children’s Hospital and the Renewable Training Centre at Sussex has been commission with construction expected to commence in 2017.
4. Build and implement innovation demonstrations on spring boxes improvement in 5 demonstration sites in Kambia and Freetown - Design for the construction of innovation facilities within existing spring boxes in Kambia and Freetown and gravity fed water in Pujehun has been commission with construction expected to commence in 2017.
5. Drill boreholes and distribution mechanisms in twelve communities in Pujehun, Kono, Kambia and Freetown - Three communities in Pujehun, three communities in Kono, four communities in Kambia and two communities in Freetown have been provided with boreholes with water distribution facilities and standing taps innovated to adapt to new aspects of climate changes projections in Sierra Leone
6. Provide water storage and treatment systems to at least 20 households in Kono and Kambia - Items (chemicals) has been provided to the Ministry of Water Resources Water storage and tre

• Train 10 WASH committee representatives to assess climate change issues, community-based adaptation planning, and household-level risk reduction interventions. • Create a sustainable communications platform in which a dialogue can ensure bottom-up decision-making process. • Design and conduct one community awareness campaign on climate change risks using culturally appropriate tools and aimed at all genders, including information packs that comprise examples of community-based adaptation measures in the water sector. • Construct twelve (12) drilled wells (boreholes) equipped with solar pump and (4 No 5m3) elevated 20,000Ltr Poly storage tanks; Fifteen (15) boreholes / monitoring wells; Three (03) Spring Box with distribution network; One (01) Gravity Water System with distribution network; Four (04) Rain Water Harvesting facilities, 6mstorage tanks and distribution network

description.narrative: Enhance the adaptive capacity of decisionmakers in the public and private sector involved in water provision to plan for and respond to climate change risks on water resources
Indicator 221 No and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks of and responses to climate variability AMAT indicator 221

comment.narrative: Technocrats from MWR and EPA in Freetown but particularly regional technical staffs have extremely limited opportunity for professional updating and usually find it difficult to address newly emerging technical issues and practices into their ongoing work One of the major limitations is the lack of capacity to deal with climate risks and understandings of managing these risks in the water sector

At least capacities of 2 line ministries and 2 Districts Council to mainstream adaptation concerns within water policies and local development plans are strengthened and capacities of two research training center to deliver relevant trainings on climate change issues of are strengthened

There has been a delay in the implementation of the project due to the outbreak of the Ebola Viral Disease and a ban on public gathering and movement of people However implementation of activities will commence in earnest in the third quarter of 2015

description.narrative: Critical public policies governing the management of water resources revised to incentivize climate smart investment by the private sector

The overall risk that climate change may pose on the sustainability of water supply to the capital not well integrated into Guma Reservoir management
Key decisionmakers who are supposed to lead the implementtaion of the policy have limited knowledge of climate change impacts or adaptation responses
Information including inventory and mapping is inadequate and staffs from MWR have limited expertise to internalize climate changes into existing local deve plan
Low interplay between public and private sector on adaptation strategies investment
Existing coping strategies and adaptation action not documented at all including for the water sector

CC resilience plan for Guma reservoir established
15 of staff from targeted institutions aware of predicted impacts of climate change and appropriate responses
60 of targeted stakeholders have access to relevant disseminated adaption experiences from the project

title.narrative: Climate Information and Early Warning Systems

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Africa for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change – Country: Sierra Leone

comment.narrative: - 20 % national coverage for climate/weather monitoring - 0 development frameworks that incorporate any EWS/CI products such as risk maps or climate change predictions into long-term planning - 0 tailored climate products developed - 0 market research survey on how household/national required early warning advisories, both supporting targeted weather/climate service delivery - 2 certified professional meteorologist 25 observers

• 2 SLMD personnel enrolled and are been trained as certified meteorologist

1. Procure and install (operationalization training) meteorological and hydrological monitoring equipment 2. Re-install AMESD-PUMA e-station and upgrade SYNERGY system to support tailored weather now-cast and forecast 3. Develop in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for Met. Technicians 4. Provide the MWR, SLMD ONS a reliable, direct and fast data and information communication system 5. Procure and install a Television and Radio Weather Broadcast equipment for forecast dissemination 6. Develop capacity programme in hydrological modelling and sector tailored hydrological forecasting techniques and information packaging 7. Establish operationalise a Climate Change Data Management System 8. Establish CBEWS at Bumbuna Watershed, Guma Valley and IVS Farms in Eastern Districts under a “Cash-for-Work” scheme

1. Procure and install (operationalization training) meteorological and hydrological monitoring equipment - Eight weather stations have been procured and installed that provide nationwide weather coverage for the weather information. - The National Hydrological Network has been re-established with associated equipment provided and trainings conducted for staff on the operationalisation of the network and information dissemination 2. Re-install AMESD-PUMA e-station and upgrade SYNERGY system to support tailored weather now-cast and forecast - The AMESD-PUMA e-station has been established and the SYNERGY system upgraded to aid the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Food Security in the dissemination of tailored forecast to farmers and agriculture producers. 3. Develop in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for Met. Technicians - In partnership with EarthNetworks Inc. on the job capacity training has been provided to staff of the Met Office on handling weather stations and dissemination of tailored weather information. 4. Provide the MWR, SLMD ONS a reliable, direct and fast data and information communication system - A Needs assessment of early warning communication network (of relevant mandated government institutions, local communities and CBOs has been conduct and communication channels between relevant mandated MDAs and local communities for dissemination of forecasting products developed. This has led to the establishment of institutional platform for collection of feedback from the community end-users on the usefulness of warning messages. A community-based communication and information sharing tool has been developed that is being pilot by CBOs as awareness raising strategy and pilot application and implementation of local level responses 5. Procure and install a Television and Radio Weather Broadcast equipment for forecast dissemination - The procurement of equipment has been deferred to 2017. However, partnership has been establis

• Develop and deliver in-service and on-the-job capacity development programme for 16 Met. Technicians (WMO Class IV) • Review current legal framework supporting EWS for issuing a warning identifying gaps and shortfalls • Conduct (4) refresher trainings on climate change risk assessments and mitigation measures for key stakeholders • Establish CBEWS at Dodo Dam (Eastern Province) and Guma Valley (Western Area) under a “Cash-for-Work” scheme and Strengthen Knowledge on Climate-Induced Risks, Emergency Preparedness and Response in the Bumbuna Watershed (Northern Province) • Develop roll-out a capacity development programme for the training of other technical personnel for SLMD

title.narrative: SECURITY SECTOR REFORM IN SIERRA LEONE

description.narrative: Security Sector Reform in Sierra Leone: Building Effective and Accountable Institutions for Increased Citizen Security

title.narrative: Sierra Leone IRF SSR prodoc signed Dec 2013 2
Evaluation of the Security Sector Programme in Sierra Leone
SECURITY SECTOR REFORM IN SIERRA LEONE
SECURITY SECTOR REFORM IN SIERRA LEONE

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Security Sector Reform in Sierra Leone: Building Effective and Accountable Institutions for Increased Citizen Security
Anti corruption

comment.narrative: Building up to 2015, a piece of legislation was enacted by Parliament leading to the establishment of the IPCB to serve as a civilian oversight to police interventions. Since establishment, the IPCB received significant support from UNDP to enable it to function and deliver much needed services to the people. UNDP contributed to the refurbishment of allocated premises as well as created the enabling environment for the new institution to operate through staff training, mentoring and coaching. UNDP in order to strengthen transparency and accountability in the management of their assets, support was provided to the SLP to develop their asset management database. Further equipment has been procured for the SLP to assist the SLP to build their capacity in the management of the database tool. Internet connectivity for the SLP Resource centre and the Asset Management Unit are nearing completion which will greatly enhance accountability for SLP’s assets nationwide and allow the resource centre to be officially opened. UNDP’s National Consultant has been working on the further design and testing of the Asset Management Database throughout the year. It will go live in 5 central locations before the end of December 2016. The Police Act of 1964 has been successfully reviewed with support from the UNDP SPC Police Advisors and SLP and other security stakeholders. The essence of the exercise was to ensure that proposed suggestions for legislation in the area take into account modern changes to ensure the modernization of the police force in their operations. The revised Act is yet to be tabled for discussions and enactment in Parliament. In the middle of the EVD epidemic in the sub-region of West Africa, UNDP’s support to the Security Sector was among other things to help build resilient institutions in the face of the menace. To ensure that the EVD virus did not enter prisons centres, UNDP provided support to the prison departments to build isolation units within 4 prison ce

In relation to the increment of female police recruits in the SLP, UNDP’s support has enabled the SLP to strengthen the gender directorate in improving on the criteria of selection of female recruits as well as provided capacity development in skills relevant to ensure proper integration of new recruits. A job fair is yet to be organized to complement trainings received with the recruitment of new female staff especially at senior level. 3 chiefdoms in the Kambia district benefited from a community policing initiative to strengthen accountability and community engagement with focus on building community-police partnership for peace preservation and social cohesion. The project resulted in the successful training of trainers (TOT) of Community Relations Officers (CROs) for partnership building in selected areas. The interventions strengthened local structures for the resolution of minor differences and community issues. Selected areas of interventions also benefited from motor bikes and other equipment to help them continue to deliver services to community even after the end of the project. A research study on Emerging Crime and Youth Violence conducted by ONS during this period was supported by UNDP, including the recruitment of a National consultant to conduct the study. The results have been received and a follow up workshop with all relevant agencies will be held early in 2017.

title.narrative: UN SUPPORT TO SIERRA LEONE CONSTITUTIONAL REVIEW PROCESS

title.narrative: Sierra leone Constitutional Review programme Document 2013-2015

UN SUPPORT TO SIERRA LEONE CONSTITUTIONAL REVIEW PROCESS

description.narrative: The Republic of Sierra Leone Constitutional Review Programme (2013-2015)
Elections - elections

# of staff Trained : Male ... Female % of trained staff (male/ female) satisfied with quality and usefulness of capacity development workshops % of CRC members (male/female) satisfied with quality and support provided by the secretariat staff # of Secretariat staff provided with induction training - Communication and messaging strategy developed # of newsletter produced Community radia station engaged in disseminating CRC's civic education public consultation messages # of copies of constitution and report produced # and tyep of activities to engaged youth in review process organized # of youth (male/female) engaged in the process - type of national and sub national civic education campaigns organized # of coordination and consensus bulding workshops between CRC and CSO's organized # of public consultation forms published and disseminated # of inclusive constitutional dialogue with focus on peace bulding and nation building topic held # of MPs (male/female) trained on dialogue, mediation and confict resulation # of CRC members (male/female) exposure visit to boserve best constitutional practices.

comment.narrative: 1. The 1991 Constitution 2. 2008 Constitutional Review Commission Report (Peter Tucker Commission Report) 3. Lome Peace Accord 4. Truth and Reconciliation Commission Report

By Decemeber 31, a training feedback report shows that at least 80% of staff trained are satisfied with its quality and usefulness (data disaggregated by sex) 40 CRC staff trained by 31st December 2015 (male:female ratio) Very transparency processes leading to the drafting of the new CRC (Rating) - Effective civic education undertaken to build knowledge of constitutional reform (Rating) - Effective and inclusiveness of public consultation process undertaken - Civil education strategy developed and effective civic education undertake to build knowledge of constitutional issues in all 149 chiefdoms - Effective public consultation process undertaken to collect feedback from across the country - All information about CRC members, CRC process and planned activities are publically available online and proactively communicated to public - Media responsibly reporting on constitutional issues and drawing on factual information from CRC in their reporting - MPs, women and youth specifically capacitated to engage constitutional process - CSOs network is established and effectively participating in the consultation process, with CSO input into CR debate, monitoring CR process and supporting civic education in all regions of the country

Fourteen Experts Meetings were organized for all Sub-Committees on key constitutional and governance related issues concerning to their thematic areas. Workshop brought together a crop of legal experts and stakeholders who critically examined the legal framework of Sierra Leone, bordering the conduct of Referendum and made recommendations for inclusion for legal provisions. These experts also drafted a comprehensive referendum Bill which has been sent to the Ministry of Justice
CRC developed an inclusive civic education strategy and engaged country’s leading TV, radio and print media outlets to disseminate and educate general public on the thematic issues and review process. Eighteen community radio stations partnered with SLBC to simulcast SLBC thematic discussions and programs at national level.
Through open public consultation and establishment of “Constitution Kiosks” the public was able to fill out submission forms and have greater understanding of issues in the review process.
30,000 Combined Document (Constitution and PTRC Report) printed and distributed nationwide. 70,000 Public Submission Forms printed and distributed 20,000 USB flash drive containing all relevant documents produced and distributed in all 14 districts of Sierra Leone. 4,000 Translated copies of the constitution distributed nationwide by NCD 45,000 Website visitors 6,000 Followers and likes on CRC Facebook page. 150 Videos uploaded on CRC YouTube Channel 20, CRC newsletter produced
a. High: CRC Plenary and sub-committees provided with high technical advice b. Final CRC Report and draft amendments/proposals produced c. Report printed and widely disseminated

a. Quality of technical advice offered to CRC Plenary and Sub-Committees to develop high quality recommendations for the CRC final report. b. 8 thematic reports have been produced c. CRC final report produced and printed in November - 2016
Key issues proposed in the CRC final report includes amendments to 171 existing and amended clauses and including Eight New Chapters and; - New Chapters in the revised constitution: 1. Local Government and Decentralization 2. Lands, Natural Resources and the Environment 3. Citizenship 4. Information, Communication and the Media 5. National Development Planning Commission 6. National Security 7. The Public Service 8. The Commissions and Independent offices
c. CRC report presented to the government of Sierra Leone (constitutional conference held)

- % Change in efficiency of cook stove technology - # of policies developed that are supported of BET application - # of certified sustainable charcoal production businesses developed as influenced by the strengthened policy and institutional frameworks for BET application - # of efficient charcoal kiln, industrial stoves and institutional furnaces/stoves being used on a daily basis by households in targeted areas

comment.narrative: - 5-30% efficient cook stoves technologies - No policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications - No certified sustainable charcoal production businesses developed - Zero installed efficient charcoal kiln, industrial stoves and institutional furnaces/stoves being used on a daily basis by households in targeted areas

1. 3 policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications draft and tabled before parliament 2. woodlots established for charcoal production 3. 1 centre of excellence for RET established 4. 5 sustainable charcoal production businesses developed as influenced by the strengthened policy and institutional frameworks for BET application

1. 3 policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications draft and tabled before parliament - The 3 policies and legal frameworks supportive of BET applications has been enacted by parliament and endorsed by the President
2. woodlots established for charcoal production - 24 hectares’ woodlot have been established in three communities in Port Loko District with active engagement by the communities including management structures with women at the helm. 3. 1 centre of excellence for RET established - A Centre of Excellence for RET has been established at the Government Technical Institute. This centre will serve as the main hub for trainings and innovation on RET
4. 5 sustainable charcoal production businesses developed as influenced by the strengthened policy and institutional frameworks for BET application - Training has been conducted in partnership with GERES for cookstove and charcoal production businesses enterprises in Freetown.

comment.narrative: About 9,524 children directed affected by the EVD since May 2014 and as of February 2015, 2, 864 patients had survived and discharged from Ebola Treatment Centers (ETCs)
2,500 survivors and destitute families socially re-inserted
Validation of existing survivors and destitute families list conducted by project teams
2,500 survivors and destitute families socially re-inserted

1,667 survivors received monthly stipends of Le350,555, while receiving livelihood skills training covering the project period. A final start-up grant for livelihood support is due at the closure of the project, estimated at Le2,500,000 to each beneficiary.

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

description.narrative: -WG established -WG knowledge of the process of developing sentencing and bail reforms is enhanced -Assessment completed with sex dis-aggregated data -Gender sensitive sentencing and bail policy adopted -General institutional and public awareness of sentencing policy enhanced -Guidelines completed and agreed by sentencing WG

comment.narrative: -No working group(WG) in place -No assessment been undertaken of current legislation and practice -No sentence policy in place -No guidance in place

1. Working Group led by the Judiciary and comprising key justice stakeholders established and capacitated to develop much needed instruments on bail and sentencing for Sierra Leone.
2. Assessment of the case management needs of the Judiciary commenced.

1. (a) Working Group established led by a senior Supreme Court Justice and with both senior members of the justice institutions and civil society working within the justice chain. (b) Key legislation and practice reviewed by the Working Group, and a south – south exchange successfully undertaken to the Judiciary of Ghana with the members of the Working Group, learning about the more recent Ghana sentencing guidelines and their experiences and challenges with respect to implementation.
2. Case management needs assessment of the Judiciary and the justice chain commenced in December 2015.

1. Bail and Sentencing Policies that are gender sensitive and developed with full respect for the principle of participation are adopted by the mandated judicial authorities (the Rules of Court Committee)
2. The suitable and viable case management system for the Judiciary is identified and implementation commenced.

1. Based on an exchange visit with senior US Federal Judges discussing best practices, 11 national consultations ensuring outreach to the whole country on present system and practice on bail and sentencing and a desk study on bail and sentencing the Working Group has finalized draft bail and sentencing instruments that are expected to be approved in November 2016.
2. Case management needs assessment finalized and feasibility assessment of APP-based case management system was finalized and presented to the Chief Justice and Senior Management of the Judiciary.
The APP-based system was identified and approved as the most suitable and sustainable case management system for Sierra Leone’s Judiciary based on the context with non-regular power and internet systems available. Implementation has commenced and will be finalized in 2017.
